sentence: Cloud computing company specialist Salesforce.com (CRM) is set to report third quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday.

The extent to which Salesforce stock, up almost 60% year to date, deserves a spot in your portfolio will be based on what the management says about the company’s growth prospects heading into the new year.
Salesforce stock entered 2017 on a hot streak, posting seven straight earnings and revenue beats.
And all the company has done this year is crush even most-bullish expectations, while outperforming the 39% rise in the PowerShares Dynamic Software ETF (PSJ).
Thanks to its leading position among the cloud, Salesforce stock has been one of the stronger growth stories in the technology sector over the past decade.
But at 66 times forward earnings, Salesforce shares aren’t cheap.
On Tuesday Wall Street will be watching closely for clues that the large-tech company can keep the growth going.
In particular, how the company performs in international marks will be of interest to investors.
As it stands, about three-quarters of the company’s revenue now comes from the Americas.

The company’s ability to capture more growth overseas will assuage investors’ uneasiness about Salesforce’s competitive standing in its core market where the likes of Microsoft (MSFT) and Oracle (ORCL) have begun to capture share.
The management understand the need to grow internationally and have begun to make the necessary investment to improve the trend.
For the quarter that ended October, Wall Street expects the San Francisco-based company to report 37 cents in earnings per share on revenue of $2.65 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when the company earned 24 cents per share on $2.14 billion in revenue.
For the full year, ending in January, earnings are projected to increase 30% year over year to $1.32 per share, while revenue of $10.4 billion would mark a 23.9% rise year over year.
In the second quarter the company beat on EPS by a penny, while revenue — which for the first time surpassed $10 billion run rate — rose some 26%.
Subscription and support revenue were also strong, climbing 26% to $2.37 billion, while Professional services and other revenue grew 28% year over year.
On Tuesday analysts will be looking to see if these metrics can continue to improve.

Likewise, there will be a focus placed on the company’s expenses to see the extent to which its overseas investments will impact the bottom line — not just for this quarter, but for the rest of the fiscal year and into 2018.
Elsewhere, the company’s deferred revenue metric, which denotes the strength of future sales, will be closely watched.
Deferred revenue, which includes some $600 million in un-billed revenue from its Demandware deal, was up 26% in the second quarter, reaching $4.82 billion.
How much of the un-billed revenue will trickle to the top line this quarter?
Of that total, will the company deliver on the bottom line, while still making investments for future growth?
One way or another, those questions will be answered Tuesday.
But even with these shares trading near their all-time high of $109, Salesforce’s ability to execute remains an appealing quality to keep this winner in your portfolio.
